messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 23, 2019 - October 29, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-10-30T19:31:40Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-10-23T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-10-29T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20191030-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=6 occurred during the synoptic period of 2019-10-25T06:00Z-09:00Z.  This moderate geomagnetic storm was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2019-10-24 (see notifications 20191025-AL-001 and 20191025-AL-002).

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-10-25T14:30Z and remained elevated for the entire reporting period.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20191025-AL-003, 20191025-AL-004, 20191027-AL-001 and 20191029-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-10-30T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-11-05T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are no significant active regions present on the solar disk visible on the available imagery.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-10-30.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-10-29T13:13:43Z
## Message ID: 20191029-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with Activity ID 2019-10-25T14:30:00-RBE-001 (notifications 20191025-AL-003, 20191025-AL-004 and 20191027-AL-001).

Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is currently around 84,000 pfu.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2019-10-24T01:00Z. 

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-10-25T14:30:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notification with ID 20191025-AL-004. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-10-25T14:30Z. Flux is currently around 90,800 pfu. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2019-10-24T01:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-10-25T14:30:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-10-25T12:11:15Z
## Message ID: 20191025-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2019-10-25T06:00Z to 2019-10-25T09:00Z. 

The storm is caused by high speed stream starting at 2019-10-24T01:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-10-25T06:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes: 




NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 09, 2019 - October 15, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-10-16T20:18:39Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-10-09T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-10-15T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20191016-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. Kp reached 4 during synoptic periods of 2019-10-09T09:00Z - 12:00Z and 2019-10-10T03:00Z-09:00Z) due to the arrival of a coronal hole high-speed stream on 2019-10-09. 

STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high-speed stream around 2019-10-11.  The solar wind speed reached values of 500 km/s on 2019-10-11.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  
Non-Earth directed:

## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.   There were no significant flares or CMEs.    

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 25, 2019 - October 01, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-10-03T02:12:45Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-09-25T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-10-01T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20191003-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2019-09-27T18:00Z-24:00Z and 2019-09-28T03:00Z-12:00Z.  This minor geomagnetic disturbance was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2019-09-27.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~700 km/s on 2019-09-27.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-09-28T14:25Z, and remained elevated until 2019-09-30.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20190928-AL-001, 20190928-AL-002 and 20190930-AL-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:

None Observed

Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-10-02T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-10-08T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There is only one small active region on the solar disk visible on the available imagery.  The geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-10-03.
